userreviews.userReview: An unhappily childless couple take a holiday in Verona, hoping to distract themselves from the heartbreak of the many failed fertility treatments they have endured. They are, however, beset by peculiar occurrences from the moment they arrive, as well as finding themselves strangely drawn to a particular church and its distinctive stained glass window... Verona seems to riff on both Daphne du Maurier's 'Don't Look Now' and the ancient religious horrors found in many of M.R. James's stories. It is subtler and, in my opinion, more effective than Abbot's Keep, the other ghost story I've read by Ashforth, and apparently his most widely read. It doesn't induce electrifying terror, but there were definitely more than a few moments that gave me chills. If you like this sort of thing then I'd certainly recommend it, and I'll be investigating the rest of Ashforth's stories at some point too.TinyLetter | Twitter | Instagram | Tumblr

Given how often modern horror writers want to dress up and pretend they’re H.P. Lovecraft, it’s always lovely to find one content to wrap himself in a comfortable old frock-coat and imagine himself M.R. James. ‘Verona: A Ghost Story’ focuses on a young couple in the 1980s who cannot have children, but such is Ashforth’s spot-on emulation of James’s late Victorian/early Edwardian prose style, there’s immediately a spooky dissonance. You may well be reading about a (fairly) modern couple trying and failing with IVF, but you can’t fail but recognize you’re in an old time ghost story. Needing a break, the couple visit Verona, where matters become swiftly spooky – in a way which has echoes of ‘Don’t Look Now’ (the film, rather than the story which I’ve shamefully never read), and the tale is, for the most part subtle, scary and mysterious. Unfortunately, by the end that subtlety has been kicked away to make room for something big and Hollywood, which is more than a tad disappointing. I wish Ashforth had had the courage of his convictions and kept true with James right to the end, to give us something opaque, wonderful and brilliant for not having all the answers.

Every October I start my "spooky reads" and this was a frighteningly creepy story. Reminiscent of M R James and earlier Susan Hill work, the well-written prose is suitably dated and the story framed within a letter, and its response. Charles and Caroline are left devastated when their dream of starting a family is ended by the specialist's diagnosis. Charles thinks a mini break would do them good and Caroline comes up with the idea of going to Verona, totally out of the blue. Whilst there, ghostly happenings take place in the street, their hotel and a church. The unsettling atmosphere follows them home, leading Caroline to research the history of their house and family with terrifying and tragic consequences. The story is horrific and inexplicable. I'm going to bang the same drum as I bang each time I read a ghost story, however. Why does a ghost, or the presence of evil, feel the need to haunt, target, possess and destroy people who have nothing to do with whatever original tragedy caused the hauntings? The ending was very good, immensely unsettling but I was left asking Sarah "why?". A writer whose work I shall seek out more of - next Halloween!

What if an extreme evil is waiting just around the corner? Waiting for a chance to enter into this world? And after years and years of trying to find the perfect host, what if it finally succeeds . . . ?Mr. Ashforth has a knack for writing dark, dreamy, horror stories that seem to come from a different era. He does not splatter the pages with gore, but instead writes horror that harkens back to a more classic time within the genre. His novellas are very deft and literate and while similar in tone they aredifferent enough in tale to be read as separate pieces. Although, what a joy it would be to combine them all in a short story/novella collection to help keep one awake at night.

FantasticAnother fantastic story. I love Benedict's mind messing style. Not jump scares but real thought provoking twisted scares. I adore the fact that he always knows how to judge the length of a book. Too short and you feel cheated. Too long and it loses its punch. These books are just right. Fantastic one sitting reading. Who knows one day I might sleep with lights off!!!!

Another satisfying read from Mr Ashforth. A good story with a semi-twist in the tale but what really shines through in Ashforth's writing is his sense of place. I could feel the sun on my face in Verona and could smell the dank mossy woods back home.I wish this author would write a longer tale.

It has a some what slow pace but that doesn’t effect anything. I was gripped on this just from reading page one. Throughout the book there is a very mysterious atmosphere, which I found a familiarity from the Historian with such a similar writing style to Elizabeth Kostova. It is very well written and I must say (since I do myself know a lot about the paranormal from research) that it is very well researched. Overall the book has Steady pace, things gradually begin to occur which I do find very realistic due to the paranormal setting. When I started reading I thought it was set in the 19th century but later discovered it wasn’t. As the plot unfolds I do warn it is, Very dark. If you do read this I wouldn’t give up, although it’s very horrific, it is worth the read. The last thing will say is that it starts off incredibly said and it ends the same but also pulls you in even more at the end. Some may find this book triggering.
